intro: Bourreria tomentosa var. havanensis, commonly known as the Havana velvetleaf, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean, particularly Cuba. It is characterized by its hairy, velvety leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers that typically bloom in clusters. The plant thrives in warm, humid climates and is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides. Its botanical features include alternate, ovate leaves with a pubescent surface and a short, erect stem. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes other plants such as hibiscus and cotton.
